question: Where can I get help with computer and online training?
answer: We have a range of resources to help build up your computing skills. When you start university, it's generally expected that you are able to use basic software (such as Microsoft Word), send emails and navigate to online materials. Here are some supports that can help to improve your computer skills: Face-to-face courses The University Preparation Program (UPP) is a free academic skills-based course to help you feel comfortable with both on-campus and online learning. Online tutorials Office 365 (Word, Excel etc) Training Centre - explore training resources for some of the common software you'll use at university. Word: Creating a Document (find for more: Word help topics ) Getting started in MyLO This online guide will help you become familiar with MyLO, the Learning Management System used at our university to access your unit information. Service Desk The Service Desk can help you sort out any issues with University computing systems - passwords, MyLO, wireless access, etc.

question: How do I contact my unit coordinator?
answer: Your Unit Coordinator's contact details are normally listed in your unit outline in MyLO and in the Course and Unit Handbook. This is the staff member in charge of your unit and is typically responsible for planning the unit, setting the assessment tasks, producing the unit outline and coordinating the teaching staff for the unit. In smaller units, the Unit Coordinator may also be your lecturer and/or your tutor.

question: As an international student, how do I access my money and how much should I bring?
answer: On arrival in Australia, you may wish to have some Australian currency in case you need to make small purchases. It is recommended that you arrive with approximately AUD$300 - AUD$500 in cash, especially if you arrive over the weekend when banks are closed. You should avoid carrying larger amounts of money. You may be able to pay for many things using your bank account from your home country. However, it's important to be aware that there could be additional transaction fees and delays. You can set up your bank account with most banks once you have arrived in Australia. Visit your chosen bank’s website to find out more about the specific documents required to open an account. As an international student, what documentation should I bring with me?

question: What is a unit code?
answer: The unit code is the three letter and three number identifier assigned to each unit. eg The unit code for Introduction to Management is BMA101. eg The unit code for Introduction to Management is BMA101. Your timetable will list your units by code; and Unit codes may be used in place of the full unit titles in communications with you. Your timetable will list your units by code; and Unit codes may be used in place of the full unit titles in communications with you.

question: Can I decline an offer that I have already accepted?
answer: You do not need to decline an accepted offer if you no longer wish to study. Provided that you have not yet enrolled in any units, your offer and acceptance will lapse on the relevant census date and no fees will be charged. However, if you want to be considered for other courses, please respond to the offer and reorder your preferences in the applications portal. If you have already enrolled in units and want to cancel your enrolment, you will first need to withdraw from those units. Find out more about how to withdraw. I have received my offer to study, what do I do next?

question: How do I apply to go on exchange?
answer: Semester 1 - opens 30 May and closes on 30 July Semester 2 - opens 30 October and closes on 28 February

question: What do I do if my Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE) is about to expire but I haven’t finished my degree?
answer: You can apply to extend your Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE) using the Confirmation of Enrolment Extension form. Complete sections 1 - 4 of the form and email it to U. Connect@utas. edu. au along with supporting documentation and a statement explaining why you need to extend your CoE. We will work out your new course end date, and if approved, you will be sent your new CoE via email. You can then use the Department of Home Affairs Document Checklist Tool to find out which other documents need to be attached to your application for a new student visa. I can't enrol, what do I do?

question: How do I know what level my unit is?
answer: You can tell by the numbers in the unit code. The first number refers to the level of the unit and generally corresponds to the year you'll take it in if you are studying full time. For example: BMA 1 01 is an introductory unit; BMA 2 07 is an intermediate unit; and BMA 3 11 is an advanced level unit.

question: When will I be able to register for classes?
answer: Before each study period MyTimetable is opened up for you to be able to choose your preferred time and day. This unit timetable is predominately for classes held on-campus classes. For online classes you will be advised directly about the time and dates. A note about preferences: Where preferences are required, you'll need to pick at least two preferences starting with 1, 2, 3 etc. Where possible, you will be registered into your highest preference with the option to swap once the preferential period has finished. Please check your timetable regularly, and again immediately before classes start, as it may have changed.

question: How do I find my unit outline?
answer: Current students: Find the outlines for units you are currently enrolled in via MyLO. This information will be available at or shortly before the start of your study period. If your unit outlines are not available via MyLO, contact your unit coordinator (search for your unit using the unit search function). Former students (e. g. applying for credit with an other institution): The Course and Unit Handbook Archive includes summary information for courses and units from 1996 and onwards. If you need more detailed information, such as a full copy of the unit outline, please contact UConnect.

question: Will changing to part time or taking a break from my study affect my scholarship?
answer: Changing to your study mode or location, or taking a break from your study, may impact your scholarship eligibility. However, this is considered on a case by case basis, as every scholarship has different terms and conditions. If you are considering changing your enrolment in any way, please let us know the proposed changes to your study and we will provide advice specific to your circumstances. Any changes are at the discretion of the scholarship selection committee and may require supporting documentation. If you are covered by the terms of a Fee-Waiver (HECS-Waiver) Scholarship, please contact UConnect.

question: Can I change my University accommodation preferences after I have submitted my application?
answer: Yes. To change accommodation preferences or other information in your application, send us an email including your name and student ID.

question: What do I do if I want to change my sponsor?
answer: YES - At the stage of accepting your offer, please provide a clear copy of your sponsorship letter or financial guarantee from your government. If you are funded by a family member and/or family member's business, this is not considered as sponsorship. If changing your sponsorship, you can upload the request and additional information to StudyLink or email International Admissions who will be able to advise you of any need for additional information. NO - I am already a student: As a current International student, if you wish to change your sponsor, you will need to submit a statement via the UConnect Contact Form (or by email to U. Connect@utas. edu. au ), formally notifying the change in sponsorship and your new sponsor will also need to provide the University with a Financial Guarantee: This is an official letter from your sponsor stating that they will cover your tuition costs (and SSAF if applicable) while you study at the University of Tasmania. This Financial Guarantee should include the following: Your Sponsor or organisation's name and contact details Your name and details Your course name, major and / or specialisation and that you are undertaking it at the University of Tasmania. The details of your sponsorship, including: The start and end dates Tuition and other fees to be covered and Overseas student health cover (single or family) Name, position and address of the sponsor's contact person (an appropriately authorised representative of your sponsor) This letter must be signed and dated by your sponsor's representative. Important: While you may be under the terms of a sponsorship, if your sponsor defaults or is unable to make payment for your fees, you, as the student, will become liable for any outstanding and future fees associated with your study. I am receiving a scholarship which covers my tuition fees. Do I need to pay the SSAF?

question: Do I need a computer and internet access to study?
answer: To access our online resources, you will need the use of a computer and an internet connection. If you are studying by distance you need these resources to complete your course requirements If you are studying on campus, some units may require online participation in discussion forums, webinars and to complete assessment tasks. If you are studying by distance you need these resources to complete your course requirements If you are studying on campus, some units may require online participation in discussion forums, webinars and to complete assessment tasks. Check your device is suitable for the online learning space, MyLO, by visiting the Student Support page and clicking on the link for "running a system check". If you do not have personal access to a computer or the internet, there are resources you can access on our campuses, including computerlabs, wifi or borrowing a laptop. If you are not able to come to campus, you should explore options in your local area such as public libraries and online access centres. Where are the computer labs? Where can I get help with computer and online training?

question: How can I get a job while I study?
answer: The best place to start looking is on CareerConnect, our online jobs portal. There you'll find a range of paid work and volunteering opportunities, including student jobs on campus as well as roles advertised by external employers. You'll also be able to access resources and assistance in applying for jobs. Other useful places to look include the job ad sites Australian JobSearch, Seek, and CareerOne, and volunteering site Volunteering Tasmania, but many jobs are not advertised - be proactive and approach employers directly as well. When finding a job, make sure it doesn't impact your studies or clash with your class times. If you are an international student, it's important also to adhere to the conditions of your student visa.

question: What is a Unique Student Identifier (USI)?
answer: A Unique Student Identifier (USI) is a number that identifies you as a student in Australia. You'll need your USI if you’re studying with us or any other higher education organisation. A valid USI must be provided by the census date of your first study period to avoid cancellation of your enrolment. Students who were studying when the USI requirement came into effect, will also need to provide a valid USI to avoid cancellation of their enrolment. Not providing a valid USI can also result in not being able to view you results or graduate. Your USI is unique to you – you only need to create it once and you have the number for life. Before you get started, make sure you have handy a form of identification that you can enter (e. g. a driver’s license or passport). The process is online and takes about 5 minutes: Go to the Unique Student Identifier site, click on 'Create a USI' and then 'Get Started' Before you’re provided with your USI, you’ll be asked to: Provide your details and evidence of identity Create a password for the USI portal Provide your details and evidence of identity Create a password for the USI portal Provide your details and evidence of identity Create a password for the USI portal Include your USI when you complete your Commonwealth Assistance Form in eStudent, or Under 'My Forms' in eStudent, select the 'Enter / Update Unique Student Identifier (USI)' form If you will be taking all of your study outside of Australia, you do not need a USI. If you are, or will be, studying in Australia you will need a USI. If you will be travelling to Australia for study, you will only be able to apply for your USI once you have arrived and gone through customs. The USI Student Portal has upgraded its security features to help protect your identity. You may now experience: Multi-factor authentication (MFA): You’ll receive a one-time code via your personal mobile or email when you create, activate, or log in to your USI account. If you don’t have access to a personal mobile or email, you’ll need to answer two security questions. Passwords now need to be a minimum of 15 characters. Using a passphrase is recommended as it’s easier to remember and harder to guess. Multi-factor authentication (MFA): You’ll receive a one-time code via your personal mobile or email when you create, activate, or log in to your USI account. If you don’t have access to a personal mobile or email, you’ll need to answer two security questions. Passwords now need to be a minimum of 15 characters. Using a passphrase is recommended as it’s easier to remember and harder to guess.

question: What are Study Periods?
answer: Study periods are set times throughout the year in which you will study. The University of Tasmania has a variety of study periods. The major ones are: Semester 1 and 2 Trimester (Accelerated Study Periods) Terms 1, 2, 3 and 4 Summer - starts January or February Winter - starts April, May or June Spring - starts October or November Each study period has its own key dates for things such as Census Date, exams, timetables, results release dates and fee payment deadlines.

question: I had a break from study. How do I return to university?
answer: Returning from an approved leave of absence: Simply log into eStudent and enrol for units in your return study period. Returning from a break without an approved leave of absence: Log into eStudent and check the status of your course. If it is 'Withdrawn' or marked as 'absent without leave' (AWOL), you will need to reapply for your course. Returning to study a new course: Contact us at U. Connect@utas. edu. au or call us on 13 8827 (13 UTAS) / +61 3 6226 6200, 9am - 5pm Monday to Friday. I want to take a break - how can I defer or pause my studies? Where can I return books to the Library?

question: What if I cancel my Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC)?
answer: If you are staying in Australia on a student visa, you must have current OSHC cover. You can only cancel your OSHC if you leave Australia permanently or start a new OSHC membership with a different provider. If you are studying in Australia on a different type of visa, you do not require OSHC and you can cancel your OSHC from the day your new visa was granted. If you complete your course early or withdraw from your studies to return home, you can also cancel your OSHC. You may be able to request a refund if you cancel your OSHC cover: The refund amount will depend on the conditions of your OSHC policy; Please contact your OSHC provider directly to cancel your cover and to request a refund if eligible. Information about Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC) I need to apply for a new student visa so I can finish my course in Australia. When do I apply and how?

question: How long is a tenancy contract with University accommodation?
answer: The standard lease terms for our accommodation are: • 42 weeks for a full academic year • 21 weeks for a single semester (limited spots available for single semester) To check in before the start of your lease contract date, please complete an early arrival accommodation request when you accept your offer of accommodation or contact our administration office as soon as possible. You may request to stay beyond your lease contract date at the end of the year. The Accommodation team will provide information about how to apply for summer extension. Requests for extensions between Semester 1 and 2 (winter break) are limited as new residents are arriving. If I arrive to my accommodation after hours how do I contact someone?

question: How do I update my details on my application?
answer: If you are a domestic student, log into the applications portal and select the 'Personal Details' tab to update your contact information. If you are an international student, please contact international. admissions@utas. edu. au for assistance.

question: What do I do if I am unwell and need an extension?
answer: Complete this online form. Contact your unit coordinator, lecturer or supervisor to let them know that you cannot be at class due to your health condition. Rest and return to campus when your symptoms are clear. FAQs – COVID-19

question: How can I nominate someone to speak on my behalf with the University (set up proxy)?
answer: If you would like us to speak with another person, eg a family member, on your behalf, you can provide permission by completing the Proxy Nomination Form. See the Forms page in the Student Portal, under 'Enrolments', or request a copy in person at your nearest UConnect location. General - we can speak with your nominated person on your behalf about any details (i. e. as if we were speaking directly to you); Enrolment - you give permission for us to discuss enrolment related matters only with your nominated person; Fees - you give permission for us to discuss fee related matters only with your nominated person. Results - you give permission for us to discuss and provide result related details with your nominated person. You can also attach a time limit to your proxy or limit it to a single course. Email U. Connect@utas. edu. au from your University webmail account and we'll remove it. If you nominated a third party to speak on your behalf when you applied for study, you will need to complete the Proxy Nomination Form if you would like this person to continue to act on your behalf once you have become a student. Third parties may include: Family (including immediate family) Friends Employers Verification agencies, etc

question: Information about parking on campus
answer: Our campuses have parking spaces available on each campus. There is Voucher Parking available on campus which costs $0. 80 per hour (marked with blue dots) and Student Permit parking which is free of charge provided you have a permit (marked with red dots). Order your student parking permit here. You'll need to create an account using your University email address. Visit the parking website for more detailed information and FAQs. I feel unsafe on campus, what should I do?

question: Can I get HECS-HELP or FEE-HELP if I study another degree?
answer: Yes, you can access HELP loans for more than one degree. The normal requirements apply: You are an eligible student (Australian Citizen, Permanent Humanitarian visa holder or NZ special category visa holder meeting the residency requirements ); You have a Tax File Number (TFN); For HECS-HELP, be accepted into a Commonwealth Supported Place (CSP). From 2020 onwards, there is a limit to the total amount of HELP debt you can accrue at any one time. See myHELPbalance and StudyAssist for details, including the current loan limit. Am I eligible to defer my fees?

question: How do I book a room in the library?
answer: You can check availability, find out room information, and book rooms through the library booking system. ​​​​​ Just choose the library you would like to book a room in, go to the date, and select the room and time that you would like to book. Please note, strict access restrictions and time limits apply. Where can I return books to the Library? Where are the libraries and when are they open?

question: What is the High Achiever and University Connections Program?
answer: The High Achiever Program and the University Connections Program allow senior secondary students in Tasmania to study at the University while they complete their schooling. Each program allows students to explore new subject areas and experience life as a university student, and results from units studied under these programs may be counted towards their ATAR. Units are covered by a full HECS scholarship and students have access to Library, IT, academic, wellbeing and recreation supports. Visit the High Achiever Program and the University Connections Program pages for more information, and to apply. What is the English Language Centre (ELC) I did not complete year 11 or 12. question: When and how will I receive my scholarship payments?
answer: Your scholarship payment/s will be made into your nominated bank account. Payment of your scholarship depends on when the scholarship commences: Before census date: payment will generally be made the first week of semester. After census: payment will generally be made two to three weeks after the census date. Payments are usually made on a Friday afternoon. If you have not received your scholarship payment by Monday of the following week, please contact the Scholarships Office. To change your nominated bank account: Log in to eStudent. Click on the My Finances button (tip: this may be on the second page, so use the right arrow to scroll across). Select Bank Details from the menu to the left of the screen. Enter your bank details, making sure they are correct.

question: What is the Student Lounge?
answer: Meet for individual and group study areas including lounges, study nooks, booths and small group meeting rooms Laptop and phone charging facilities Kitchen facilities including microwaves boiling water and TUSA provided tea / coffee The Sandy Bay Student Lounge, located between Lazenby's and the Administration Building, across from the Morris Miller Library, open Monday - Friday, 8am - 5pm The TUSA Lounge, TUSA Building (above the old Suzie Lee cafe), Sandy Bay campus, open Monday - Friday, 8am - 5pm The Launceston Lounge, located in Building Z on the Newnham campus, open Monday - Friday, 8am - 5pm The Burnie TUSA Office, open Monday - Thursday 8: 30am - 4: 30pm KPMG Building in Hobart city, 137 Harrington St, open Monday - Friday 7am - 8pm Hobart City Student Hub, 157 Melville St, open Monday - Friday, 9am - 5pm

question: What is the English Language Centre (ELC)
answer: The University English Language Centre offers a variety of English language teaching programs taught by fully qualified, highly committed teachers. The latest teaching methods ensure that classes stimulate, motivate and enable students to move rapidly through the different levels of competency to reach their study goals. The English Language Centre is located at the Phillip Smith Centre, Domain, Hobart. Students have full access to University services and have all the discount benefits available to other University students for transport, accommodation, books, cinema, gym, etc. Whether you need to improve your English to qualify for further study, or you want to enhance your job opportunities, the University English Language Centre has a program that will suit. For more information please visit the ELC website.

question: What should I do if I fail a pre-requisite unit?
answer: ​ You will need to re-enrol in the unit if it is a core (required) unit for your course. You can find detailed unit information, including availabilities, in the Course and Unit Handbook and in your course planner in your Student Portal. If you would like some advice about your study plan and unit options, please contact UConnect or speak with a Student Adviser.

question: What financial support is available for students?
answer: University of Tasmania in conjunction with the Tasmanian University Student Association (TUSA) offers Financial Assistance through the Student Financial Hardship Scheme. See ' Financial and Legal Support ' for more information. If you are experiencing financial hardship and meet the eligibility requirements, you can access assistance for food and groceries or other essential items. The Tasmanian University Student Association (TUSA) offers free Financial counselling. International student support services

question: How do I enrol as a cross-institutional student?
answer: University of Tasmania students applying to study at another institution: Cross-institutional study is only approved in certain circumstances, and you must receive approval before you apply to study with another institution to ensure that the unit you want to take is equivalent to your UTAS unit and can be counted towards your course. Approval to take a core or major unit by cross-institutional study may only be granted in limited circumstances. Check the Outbound Cross-Institutional Guidelines and Application Form (find this on the Forms page in your Student Portal ) to find out more about how to apply and contact UConnect if you have any questions about your options. Once you have identified the unit you want to take with another institution, you will need to submit your ‘outbound cross-institutional study form’ to UConnect. If your application is approved, you will need to contact your host institution to find out how to apply and enrol with them. Complete the ' Incoming Cross Institutional Application for Admission and Enrolment ' form (check the Guidelines for Incoming Cross-Institutional Admission and Enrolment for more information) Once you have been admitted and enrolled, if you are in a Commonwealth Supported Place, please ensure you then complete the ‘Request for Commonwealth Support and HECS-HELP’ eCAF in eStudent by the Census Date. I can't enrol, what do I do?

question: I am a primary carer - is there any support available to me?
answer: Yes. We provide support to students who are primary carers for a person with a disability, long-term illness, mental health condition, or someone who is frail / aged. To be assessed, you and a Health Practitioner will need to complete the Guidelines and Arrangements for Students who are Primary Carers form (find at the bottom of this page). Options for submitting the form Attach the form when making an appointment Email the completed form to Accessibility. Services@utas. edu. au Provide in person at a UConnect location File Type pdf Carers Plan Application Form. pdf (174. 76 KB)

question: What is a Health Practitioner's report (HPR)?
answer: A Health Practitioners report is a document from your doctor which provides relevant information regarding the functional implications of the disability or health condition on the student’s capacity to participate in and access study. Implications may include difficulties with processing visual/aural information, concentration, fatigue, pain, mobility, physical dexterity, and social interaction. Download the form: Access to Assistance for Students with Disabilities / Health Condition form You can then submit this form when registering with the Accessibility Service. I am a primary carer - is there any support available to me?

question: Emergency and urgent help on campus
answer: In an emergency or if you require urgent help or assistance, do not hesitate to contact emergency services (Police, Ambulance, Fire Brigade) by calling 000. You can also contact on-campus security directly by accessing a Help Point telephone which are available at numerous locations across campus. Pressing the button on the Help Point will put you in contact with Security directly. Check the Campus Maps to find the locations of the Help Points. If you cannot access a Help Point, for urgent matters please call security immediately on: All Campuses: (03) 6226 7600 (save this number in your phone) I feel unsafe on campus, what should I do?

question: Why can't I find or register for classes in MyTimetable?
answer: You are studying the unit off campus. Only the units you study on campus will appear in your personal timetable, with just a few exceptions. You are not enrolled in the unit. Note, it can take up to 24 hours from the time you enrol in the unit for it to show in your timetable. The unit does not have any timetabled activities. More information may be available in Courses and Units, the unit outline, or MyLO. The timetable may not have been released yet. Check the timetable release dates. You may be studying a unit through one of the following Colleges or Schools that has a different method for accessing your timetable: Conservatorium of Music - For the timetabling information, please refer to the Conservatorium Student Resources. Medicine - Tasmanian School of Medicine timetables are available in MyLO a week before semester begins. Maritime Training - For timetabling information, please refer to the AMC Timetable. Bachelor of Pharmacy or Master of Pharmaceutical Science - you are part of a pilot program trialling a new system of class allocation. Find out more.

question: Can I get career support?
answer: Yes. There are a range of resource available to help you kick start you career. Visit the Jobs and Careers page in the Student Portal to find out more. You can also access Career Connect online - a jobs portal that also offers a suite of career and leadership development support, including: part-time, casual, and graduate job opportunities; career events and workshops; personalised feedback on your resume and job application; mock interviews; volunteering opportunities; and more.

question: My school does not appear in the applications portal. What do I do?
answer: If the school you attended in year 12 does not appear in the applications portal, please contact course. info@utas. edu. au for assistance. Please note, schools in the Northern Territory will be listed in the drop-down menu for South Australia. If you have any further enquiries, please contact course. info@utas. edu. au. question: What College am I in?
answer: Tasmanian School of Business and Economics (some examples are Accounting, Management, Marketing, Tourism). College of Arts, Law and Education (some examples are Creative Arts, Media and Communication, Education, Law, Humanities and Social Science). College of Sciences and Engineering (some examples are Marine Science, ITS, Architecture and Design, Natural Science, Sustainable Living, AMC and Institute of Agriculture). College of Health and Medicine (some examples are Medicine, Nursing, Pharmacy, Psychology and Health Science).

question: What public transport is available?
answer: Transport options across our campuses can be found on Unimaps. Hobart / Sandy Bay campus The free UniHopper runs throughout the day to get you between our Hobart City locations, the Sandy Bay campus and accommodation. UniHopper Timetable All Tasmanian campuses Metro buses run very frequently between Hobart, Launceston and Cradle Coast campuses and their city centres, and also offer suburban services directly from some campuses. Access timetables via the Metro website. If taking public transport, using a Greencard is the most convenient way to pay for bus travel. Apply and find out more on the Metro Greencard website. Launceston intercampus bus Metro provides a free service for students and staff travelling between Newnham and Inveresk campus, including the city and Launceston General Hospital. Find more details here. Sydney campus There are buses and trains that go to Lilyfield. I am a primary carer - is there any support available to me?

question: Can I go over the assessment word count?
answer: Generally speaking word limits for an assessment will carry with them a 10% buffer zone above and below the stated limit. In some cases this may be made explicitly clear by your lecturer or they may state that the word limit is to be adhered to with no flexibility. Please note that assessment rules and guidelines vary so for clarification please refer directly to your unit outline, College guidelines or speak to your teacher.

question: What is swotvac?
answer: Swotvac is short for Study Without Teaching Vacation. This is the week that falls between the end of Semester 1 or 2 and the start of the exam period. Online exams. What do I need to know?

question: How do I print?
answer: Log out using the arrow in the top right corner

question: What is eStudent?
answer: eStudent is the system where you will manage the administrative aspects of your study including: Enrolling in units Updating your contact details Accessing your exams timetable and Viewing your graduation eligibility Access eStudent directly or via your Student Portal.

question: What support and services are available for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students?
answer: Riawunna provides the following services and resources: Academic support and advice Assistance with applications for bursaries, scholarships and cadetships Cultural and social support and events Murina Program Pastoral care Resource collection featuring Aboriginal literature and resources Spaces for studying and relaxing Aboriginal Student Adviser for assistance and referral for academic/personal issues Tutoring services

question: What is OS-HELP?
answer: OS-HELP is a loan available to eligible students in a Commonwealth Supported Place (CSP) that provides financial assistance to take part of your University of Tasmania study overseas. Your full-time overseas stud y must b e eligible to count towards your course at the University of Tasmania You can access one loan per six-month study period and can access a total of two OS-HELP loans over your lifetime. For more information about OS-HELP, including eligibility requirements and the maximum amount you can borrow for where you will study, check Study Assist OS-HELP. To apply, complete the OS-HELP Loan Assistance form ( Forms page in your Student Portal ). For more information on funding overseas study that will count towards your degree, visit the Learning Abroad page in your Student Portal. Am I eligible to defer my fees?

question: Does the University have a harassment and discrimination policy?
answer: Our Behaviour Policy covers all staff and students, and sets out what is expected from all of us. We want you to feel safe and comfortable while studying at our University. Harassment, bullying and discrimination will not be tolerated and action can be taken to stop these behaviours. There are processes in place to deal with harassment and discrimination complaints and people you can talk with about your options. This includes: The Safe and Fair Community Unit Student Advisers Safety and Security Team Personal Counsellors Your Supervisors, Unit Coordinators, or trusted staff who can help direct you.

question: Can someone else collect my testamur or degree certificate for me?
answer: You will need to provide written authorisation for someone else to collect your testamur or degree certificate. Please contact U. Connect@utas. edu. au. I have changed gender. Can I get a new testamur (degree certificate) with my new name on it?

question: Can I get a refund on my SSAF if I withdraw?
answer: Refund of the Student Services and Amenities Fee (SSAF): If you are withdrawing after the census date, we are unable to refund the SSAF for that unit. If you are withdrawing on or before the census date - and have already paid your SSAF up front - you will have a credit for this amount that will be applied for your next enrolment. If you are no longer studying you can apply for this credit to be returned to you by submitting a ' Request for Fees Refund (PDF 229. 0 KB) '.

question: I feel unsafe on campus, what should I do?
answer: All Campuses: (03) 6226 7600 In the case of an emergency do not hesitate to contact emergency services (Police, Ambulance, Fire Brigade) by calling 000. You should put the Security phone number for your campus in your phone so you can access it readily. It is recommended that you also download the SafeZone app to your mobile phone. You can also phone from Help Points located around the campuses: Find the location of Help Points via UniMaps. If you are feeling unsafe or that you may be in danger while you are on campus, our security officers can escort you between buildings, campus car parks and local public transport points on campus. If you have a question about facilities or services on campus, you can visit Campus Services. Information about parking on campus Emergency and urgent help on campus

question: What do I need to do before Census Date?
answer: Complete your eCAF Provide your tax file number Complete an SA-HELP form if you want to defer your tuition and SSAF If you are not deferring your fees, make your upfront payments Check your fee invoice in eStudent to make sure that any fee-waivers or sponsorships have been applied Make full payment for your study period or submit an application for a payment plan Check your fee invoice in eStudent to make sure that any fee-waivers or sponsorships have been applied Send a copy of your receipt to the UConnect team if any payments you have made are not showing on eStudent yet (please allow at least 5 days for the payment to be received) See also: I paid my SSAF / completed SA-HELP form but I still have a sanction or outstanding fees on my invoice. Why? I made a payment to the University: why can’t I see it on eStudent?

question: My testamur has not arrived in the mail. What can I do?
answer: If you have not received your testamur and it has been more than 6 weeks since your ceremony, please email U. Connect@utas. edu. au or phone 13 8827 (13 UTAS) / +61 3 6226 6200. If you did not attend your graduation ceremony, your testamur will be sent via registered post 4-6 weeks after the ceremony date. We use your preferred address as recorded in eStudent (go to the 'Contacts' section of the 'My Details' tab).

question: Am I entitled to Superannuation if I am an international student?
answer: Temporary residents of Australia are entitled to superannuation but we recommend you use the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) tool to check your entitlement while working and when you depart Australia: How superannuation applies to temporary residents | Australian Taxation Office (ato. gov. au). I need to apply for a new student visa so I can finish my course in Australia. When do I apply and how?

question: How do I get my graduation details verified by another organisation?
answer: You can find your graduation information (name, graduation year, and degree) on our Online Graduation Verification Service. If you need verification of additional details, please contact us via the Online Contact Form to grant permission for your details to be released. If you are using a personal email address, please include your full name, date of birth, student ID number and the name of the course you were studying. Am I eligible to graduate?

question: What is a Commonwealth Assistance Notice (CAN)?
answer: Your CAN is your official notification of your enrolment at the University of Tasmania. Your CAN includes information on: The Student contribution amounts or tuition fees for your units of study Any upfront payment you have made, or which have been made on your behalf Any reductions or discounts you may have received (eg. HECS fee scholarships) Any HECS-HELP loan you have used for that study period Any Student Services & Amenities Fees (SSAF) you have incurred To check if you currently have any fees outstanding you will need to generate an invoice through eStudent.

question: How can I maintain or improve my physical and mental wellbeing while studying?
answer: Physical Wellbeing Resources UniGym is a multi-purpose fitness centre with locations on the Sandy Bay, Newnham and Cradle Coast campuses. UniGym provides health and fitness services and sporting facilities for use by university students and staff, as well as community members. UTAS Sport offers opportunities to experience something new and have fun, as well as opportunities for those wanting to pursue sport at its highest level. Student Clubs and Societies also provide physically engaging and fun activities such as acrobatics, bush walking and dancing. Mental Health and Wellbeing Resources Our University provides a range of support for mental health and wellbeing including personal counselling, interactive webinars, drop-in mindfulness and a range of self-help resources. After hours counselling and crisis services

question: What are reading lists and how do I access them?
answer: The Reading Lists system is a list of the required and recommended textbooks and eReadings for your unit, as requested by your lecturer. You can also access your reading list in MyLO via the 'Reading Lists' link under the unit information page. Where can I find my textbooks for my course?

question: How do I provide my academic results if I am a cross-institutional student?
answer: If you are studying units at the University of Tasmania, you will need to provide your home institution with a copy of your Official Academic Transcript. If you are studying units at another institution that will be counted towards a University of Tasmania degree, you will need to provide us with your official academic transcript (original, certified copy, or secure digital copy ). We are unable to obtain this document on your behalf. You will see a WT grade code if you have not yet provided your results to us. For more detail, visit the Learning Abroad page in your Student Portal.

question: What do I do if I have lost something on campus?

question: I did not complete year 11 or 12. Can I still apply for university?
answer: Yes. In some instances, depending on your work experience, you may be admitted directly into a course. We also offer pathway programs to full degree programs, as well as bridging and foundation units, usually offered during the Spring and Summer semesters. For more information about your potential entry into an undergraduate course, please contact us on 13 UTAS (13 88 27) or at Course. Info@utas. edu. au

question: Can I break my University accommodation lease and move out during the term of the lease?
answer: When you accept your Offer of Accommodation, you enter into a legally binding contract. You are required to inform us in writing about your intention to vacate and there are forms in the Resident Portal which you need to fill-in to complete the process. Your case will be managed by the accommodation team who will assess if there are any penalties incurred. If you have any questions, reach out to enquiries@accommodation. utas. edu. au. You are responsible for payment of rent until the end of your contract; or if approved, the date of your break lease.

question: Can I get into a unit that is already full?
answer: If you can't enrol yourself in a unit because it has reached its quota (maximum number of students), contact the unit coordinator to check if it is still possible for you to enrol. If the unit coordinator approves your enrolment, forward their approval email to u. connect@utas. edu. au. It may take a couple of days for you to then be enrolled.

question: As an international student, what documentation should I bring with me?
answer: As an International student, you should ensure that you bring the following important documents: Your Confirmation of Enrolment and Letter of Offer Any original or certified documents requested in the conditions of your Letter of Offer Current passport Other official identification (eg driver's licence, ID card etc) Any medical records (particularly immunisations) and personal medications with supporting documentation (ie doctor's prescription). Please refer to the Australian Government Therapeutic Goods Administration website ( www. tga. gov. au ) for more information about bringing medications to Australia. As an international student, how do I access my money and how much should I bring? International student support services

question: What is the Course and Unit Handbook?
answer: The Course and Unit Handbook is an online resource that contains information on all of the courses (degrees) and units offered. If you are applying for study or getting ready to enrol, the Course and Unit Handbook will help you: Find out about your course, what choice of units you have, where it is available, and how long it will take to complete. Find out about a unit, how / when / where it is taught, what the assessment requirements are, and who to contact. Check your text book requirements.

question: Is there a UniGym on campus?
answer: We have UniGyms on three campuses: in Hobart, Launceston and Burnie. There are a range of membership options for students, staff and the community. We also have a range of facilities that you can book, including: Squash courts Basketball courts Badminton courts Football ovals Tennis courts Cricket ovals/nets Dojo and Swimming pool Find out more and view the UniGym opening hours on the website.

question: What happens if I don't pay my SSAF?
answer: If you do not pay your Student Services and Amenities Fee (or any other fee that the University has charged you), then you will have a sanction placed on your account. A sanction will prevent you from: Viewing your results (for any study) in eStudent Having a completion letter issued Having an unofficial faculty record issued Graduating (even if you have met the academic requirements of your course) See also: What does it mean to have a sanction or Fees Overdue?

question: What is the Safe and Fair Community Unit?
answer: The Safe and Fair Community Unit (SaFCU) is a University-wide service providing support, advice and information to assist our community members to be safe and well. They respond to notifications of sexual assault or sexual harassment, concerns raised in relation to wellbeing or behaviour, reports of inappropriate behaviour and the lodgement of general concerns or complaints. If you have experienced something which impacts on safety or wellbeing, or you wish to make a complaint, we encourage you to contact the Safe and Fair Community Unit. Staff are there to listen, provide information and advice regarding your options and support, and where appropriate, will facilitate actions to assist you with your situation. The University's Behaviour Policy and resources that support this can be found on the University Policy website.

question: How do I join the alumni community after I graduate?
answer: My testamur has not arrived in the mail. What can I do? Am I eligible to graduate?

question: Can I take a unit from another university (cross-institutional study)?
answer: Yes, provided you have submitted an application for outbound cross-institutional study and received approval to take a unit from another university, and have it count towards your course. Approval to take a core or major unit by cross-institutional study may only be granted in limited circumstances. Check the Outbound Cross-Institutional Guidelines and Application Form (find this on the Forms page in the Student Portal ) to find out more about how to apply and contact UConnect if you have any questions about your options. Once you have identified the unit you want to take with another institution, you will need to submit your ‘outbound cross-institutional study form’ to UConnect. If your application is approved, you will need to contact your host institution to find out how to apply and enrol with them.

question: Does Riawunna have Scholarships for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students?
answer: There are a number of scholarships and bursaries available to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander students. Students can apply for the "University of Tasmania Indigenous Scholarships" and they will be assessed for the following awards: takamuna Scholarship for Education Costs takamuna Scholarship for Accommodation Riawunna palanawina Accommodation and Living Allowance Scholarship Riawunna Access Bursary Medical Student 'Aboriginal Entry Application Process Funding Scheme Grant Lucy Beeton Aboriginal Teacher Scholarship Lech Kula Scholarship tunapri rrala Scholarship for Tasmanian Aboriginal Students takumuna Rosie Smith Law Scholarship My course was supposed to be free, why are there fees on my invoice?

question: How do I report an incident or hazard?
answer: Incidents involving physical injury, illness, or a "near miss": Report the incident or hazard on MySAFETY. A broken door that won't close properly (report as a 'Hazard') You hurt your hand trying to get through a broken door (report as an 'Injury') Incidents involving bullying, harassment, sexual harassment or assault, intimidation, disrespect, or threatening behaviour: Report these to the Safe and Fair Community Unit (SaFCU). Find the public link here. Example: You have been threatened by a student or staff member I feel unsafe on campus, what should I do?

question: How do I use and install Respondus Lockdown Browser?
answer: Some online exams and assessments will require you to use a lockdown browser to limit your internet and PC access to ensure that our academic integrity guidelines are upheld. Download Respondus LockDown (also available to download in MyLO), and Follow the prompts to install the software. For more detailed instructions visit the Using Respondus LockDown Browser and Monitor webpage. Online exams. What do I need to know?

question: University terminology and glossary
answer: Confused by words and terms used by universities? Don't be! Visit the University Glossary for the full list of terms.

question: I’m an international student. How do I apply to transfer to another Australian education provider?
answer: If you are studying at the University of Tasmania on a Student Visa and have not completed 6 months of study in your principal course, you may need to request approval to transfer to another Australian education provider. More information about applying to transfer to another Australian education provider can be found in our International Student Transfer Request Procedure. Transfer Education Provider and Release Request Application Forms and supporting documentation should be emailed to U. Connect@utas. edu. au. I am studying at another University, how do I transfer to the University of Tasmania? I paid my SSAF / completed SA-HELP form but I still have a sanction or outstanding fees on my invoice. Why?

question: How do I report sexual harassment or sexual assault?
answer: Your wellbeing and safety is our priority. If you have experienced or witnessed an incident of sexual assault or sexual harassment, please contact the Safe and Fair Community Unit (SaFCU) who will provide advice and guidance on support services options and reporting options. Gender-based violence is defined as any form of physical or non-physical violence or abuse by a person that is underpinned by gender-based power inequalities, rigid gender norms and gender-based discrimination that results in, or is likely to result in, harm, coercion, control, fear or deprivation of liberty and autonomy. Gender based violence includes sexual assault, rape, and sexual harassment. Student Portal houses more resource for a safe community, including forms to report sexual misconduct and more on the process of disclosing sexual misconduct. How to contact SaFCU The SaFCU phone number is: +61 3 6226 2560 The SaFCU email is: SaFCU@utas. edu. au Sexual assault is a crime. A victim or witness to sexual assault is encouraged to report the matter to the police. Please contact Tasmania Police or NSW Police (for Rozelle campus students). I feel unsafe on campus, what should I do?

question: Will my Honours level appear on my testamur?
answer: No. Your testamur (graduation certificate) will only show the course you have been awarded, not the level of Honours (e. g. First Class, Second Class). Your official academic transcript will list the level of Honours you have received. I have changed gender. Can I get a new testamur (degree certificate) with my new name on it?

question: How do I find my unit in MyLO?
answer: Go to the MyLO home page, Click the 'Select a Unit' icon (square icon at the top of the page), Click on your unit (this will take you into the unit's home page), Select the 'Content' tool (top of page), and Click to the 'Table of Contents'. Here you will see a list of the 'modules' that make up your unit. Next to each module is a number indicating how many 'topics' it contains.

question: Can I enrol or be re-admitted when my exclusion is over?
answer: When your exclusion is over, you will need to re-apply for the course you were excluded from if you wish to continue studying. Re-admission and enrolling is not automatic. Before you re-apply, contact a Student Adviser to discuss your situation, any potential changes to your course, your credit eligibility, and what supports are available to help you if you decide to return to study. If you are an international student, please make an appointment with an International Student Adviser to discuss your options. If you need help booking an appointment, please contact UConnect. If you have been excluded, whether permanently or temporarily, from any tertiary institution in Australia or elsewhere, you must include a statement with all details of the exclusion or suspension in your application. This includes: The circumstances surrounding your academic history; The activities you have undertaken since your exclusion, including information about any employment – paid or voluntary, and studies you have undertaken; and The plans you have put in place to prevent a recurrence of the circumstances which lead to your exclusion. The factors for re-admission taken into account include: Your total academic record; Your activities since exclusion, including any relevant employment and studies; Any evidence to suggest a change in capacity, attitude or motivation; and Whether there is competition for, or availability of, places in the course. If your original course is no longer offered, you can apply into an alternate course. Visit the applications page for more information.

question: What does 'quota restricted' mean? How do I know if the courses have a quota?
answer: Some courses are restricted to admitting a certain number of students: These are said to have a 'quota'. For more information and to see the current list of quota courses, see the Admissions Selection page.

question: What is academic writing?
answer: This is the style of writing used at university to: Discuss complex concepts Explain how things work Explore arguments for or against ideas Demonstrate critical thinking and Visit the Study Toolkit to access the Academic Writing module and keep an eye out for a live Academic Writing webinar (or access previous webinar recordings) for more information. Where can I find information on and help with referencing?

question: Will I be eligible for Abstudy?
answer: ABSTUDY helps with costs for Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander peoples who are studying. To get ABSTUDY, you must: Be of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander Australian descent Identify as an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander Australian Be accepted as such by the community in which you live or have lived Be an Australian citizen and normally live in Australia, and Be covered under 1 of the 7 ABSTUDY Awards - ABSTUDY Awards describe eligibility for the different payments and allowances available under ABSTUDY If you are interested in applying for ABSTUDY contact 1800 132 317.

question: What are Foundation Units and do I need them?
answer: Foundation units can help you meet an entry requirement for your degree or refresh your knowledge before starting. Available units cover areas such as: Chemistry Mathematics Physics Programming preparation Check the entry requirements for the course you are interested in by finding the relevant course page in the Course and Unit Handbook. If you meet all the entry requirements apart from the unit prerequisites, it is likely you will need to take a foundation unit. Conditional offer If your offer is conditional on you completing a foundation unit, your letter of offer will list the unit(s) you need to complete before you can start. Foundation units are offered fully online and timed so you can complete them before the start of semester. Check the foundation units and pathway programs pages for more details. More information If you are unsure what to study and would like to check with us, please call 13 88 27 (13 UTAS) or email course. info@utas. edu. au I did not complete year 11 or 12. Can I still apply for university?

question: What is the SafeZone app?
answer: SafeZone is an app for your mobile device that allows you to quickly and easily contact Campus Security to request assistance. The SafeZone app is available free for all students and staff and operates across all of our campuses and facilities. Click here to find out more or to download the app (strongly recommended). question: What do I do if I think my Commonwealth Assistance Notice (CAN) is incorrect?
answer: Replying to the CAN notification email, or Email UConnect specifying the details that are incorrect.
